title: Convert UUencode to new bytesarray approach
body:
Forgot about this one:
https://github.com/sabnzbd/sabnzbd/blob/2058a4b6399d58a8f01583ab73cca7c43f12e09a/sabnzbd/decoder.py#L152-L155

Reminder for myself or anyone else that this needs to be fixed before 4.0.0-Final.

> There’s a change to the implementation of the msdos and exfat file systems. Apps that check for those specific file system formats might not detect them. Please file feedback if this impacts your app. (90768681)

trying to find out exactly what changed

title: Multi-edit applying category + something else can have unpredictable results
body:
When applying job-settings using multi-edit, the results can be unpredictable because for each of the items (Category/Priority/Scripts/Post Processing) we sent a separate API request.
However, a category can also set some of the other 3 settings.
So it depends which API request is processed first if the Category-version of Priority/Scripts/Post Processing is applied, or the one specified by the user in the multi-edit.
Solution seems simple: first apply the category and only then send the API requests for the other settings.

title: Download hangs forever if server cannot be resolved
body:
If a server's hostname cannot be resolved then a download trying to check against it will hang forever. Disabling the server, pausing and restarting the download, restarting sab entirely, does not allow it to recover. Only removing the download entirely and re-importing (or the server in question coming back online) seems to allow it to resume.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8425502/198843471-8253308c-1b3a-47ef-85a4-1b0f9bd6d7cc.png)

I would have assumed that there was some kind of timeout in place for name resolution, similar to or using the timeout value attached to the server configuration, but it never seems to fail and just tries indefinitely.

Running 3.7.0 RC1 in docker.

title: Free Space Detection wrong when using Direct Unpack
body:
It seems to me, that sabnzbd wants to have at least twice the size of what is already downloaded available, which cant be right in my opinion, if direct unpack is enabled.

For more details please visit this Forum post:
https://forums.sabnzbd.org/viewtopic.php?t=25957

title: Test failure in TestPar2Repair.test_broken_filejoin
body:
The assert at [test_newsunpack.py:133](https://github.com/sabnzbd/sabnzbd/blob/a6d07d89d0b56e99f3b47f191d1688a4b9535772/tests/test_newsunpack.py#L133) fails in case the repair takes longer to complete than the 0 seconds hardcoded in the expected function call, e.g. with high enough system loads and/or on lower spec systems.

This could probably be worked around by leveraging something like [callee](https://callee.readthedocs.io/en/latest/reference/strings.html#patterns) (nice but not really worth the extra dep) or by manually checking the argument string info stored by mock rather than using `assert_has_calls()` for that (which AFAIK doesn't accept globbing or regular expressions).

Log excerpt from [Debian CI](https://ci.debian.net/data/autopkgtest/testing/amd64/s/sabnzbdplus/25082821/log.gz):
```

caplog = <_pytest.logging.LogCaptureFixture object at 0x7ffb57e2e8c0>

>       nzo, dir_contents = self._run_par2repair(

        )

tests/test_newsunpack.py:288: 
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 
tests/test_newsunpack.py:134: in _run_par2repair
    nzo.set_unpack_info.assert_has_calls(
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 

self = <Mock name='mock.set_unpack_info' id='140717423965424'>
calls = [call('Repair', '[test] Verified in 0 seconds, repair is required'), call('Repair', '[test] Repaired in 0 seconds')]
any_order = False

    def assert_has_calls(self, calls, any_order=False):
        """assert the mock has been called with the specified calls.
        The `mock_calls` list is checked for the calls.
    
        If `any_order` is False (the default) then the calls must be
        sequential. There can be extra calls before or after the
        specified calls.
    
        If `any_order` is True then the calls can be in any order, but
        they must all appear in `mock_calls`."""
        expected = [self._call_matcher(c) for c in calls]
        cause = next((e for e in expected if isinstance(e, Exception)), None)
        all_calls = _CallList(self._call_matcher(c) for c in self.mock_calls)
        if not any_order:
            if expected not in all_calls:
                if cause is None:
                    problem = 'Calls not found.'
                else:
                    problem = ('Error processing expected calls.\n'
                               'Errors: {}').format(
                                   [e if isinstance(e, Exception) else None
                                    for e in expected])
>               raise AssertionError(
                    f'{problem}\n'
                    f'Expected: {_CallList(calls)}'
                    f'{self._calls_repr(prefix="Actual").rstrip(".")}'
                ) from cause

E                call('Repair', '[test] Repaired in 0 seconds')]
E               Actual: [call('Repair', '[test] Verified in 0 seconds, repair is required'),
E                call('Repair', '[test] Repaired in 1 sec')]

/usr/lib/python3.10/unittest/mock.py:956: AssertionError
```

title: Feature Request: Check before download notice

title: Aggressive deobfuscation occasionally renames files that shouldn't be renamed
body:
I've noticed lately that in some cases, when downloading MP3 music scene releases, one or two (empirically it's either none, one or two, never more) MP3 files are renamed to the NZB name.

Today I took a look at the debug log and it looks like it's an aggressive (and unnecessary) deobfuscation attempt that causes the issue.

I've uploaded an extract of the debug log [here](https://0bin.net/paste/sk+GZxjF#CS6fs-iVQuqoN3JEjXh2iN7dGhhu7IpFBhqSAlHtiVS), the relevant bit starts at line 451.

Also, it's probably unrelated but there are two mentions of using the "tv sorter" for the download, even though it's categorized and music and eventually treated as such (lines 74 and 510).

The NZB file is [here](https://anonfiles.com/d8Gf9es0y6/Mark_Knopfler-Down_The_Road_Wherever-_Deluxe_Edition_-2018-RiBS_nzb).

Thanks for the attention, I'll be happy to do tests or provide more information if necessary.

title: nscript_parameters value does not accept quotes
body:
I am using NZB-Notify for Slack notifications, with the settings:
`
nscript_script = sabnzbd-notify.py
nscript_parameters = complete "%2" "%3" slack://<...>/<...>/<...>/sabnzbd
`

 From the UI, I noticed it only shows "complete" in the parameters even though everything is in  the INI file. But if you press "Save" in that section, it actually overrides the value to "complete", which means that integration no longer works.

The UI's HTML code is as below:

`
<input type="text" name="nscript_parameters" id="nscript_parameters" value="complete " %2"="" "%3"="" slack:="" <...>="" <...>="" <...>="" sabnzbd"="">
`
which is clearly broken. 

Maybe you are meant to wrap it on another script and just point to this but it would be nice to work as intended.

title: Sample-detection broken for `.par2` files
body:
Some users reported it on the forums, but now I also saw it myself: the sample detection based on `guessit` is just not working well enough.
Files like `last.week.tonight.with.john.oliver.s08e26.1080p.web.h264-glhf-sample.par2` or not detected as a sample.
@jcfp Maybe we should just go back to the old method with the super-simple regex?
Despite theoretical cases in which it would fail (as shown in the unittests), did we even get real-life complaints? I don't remember any.
Seems `guessit` just can't handle this well.

title: Sorter requires `%ext`
body:
The new 3.4.0 sorter requires `%ext` to be used in the Sort string, otherwise it will just fail the download.
Reported here: https://forums.sabnzbd.org/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=25559&p=125885#p125885
Apparently this was not the case before 3.4.0 and SABnzbd also doesn't warn that not using `%ext` is invalid.
@jcfp can we restore the old behavior?
Example: `%sn/Season %0s/%dn`

title: Crashed downloader stops all downloads, even after restart?
body:
Running v3.4.0 on OSX 10.15.7. 

Yesterday SAB was happily downloading, it then seemed to "freeze" (in the background, I wasn't watching) with lots of jobs "remaining". Manual "start" or "force" via the icons/GUI made no difference. Nor did rebuilding the queue etc.

I even used the GUI to restart SAB without any success. This morning (by the computer) I did "force quit" via "Activity Monitor" and restart. The same issue happens.

title: NzbQueue.reset_try_lists could result in jobs stuck at 99%
body:
After reports of jobs being stuck at 99%on the forums and Reddit, I found a very helpful user on Reddit that helped me find the cause.

In 3.2.0 I refactored the `__reset_nw` function and CRC errors were retried on all servers. 
I introduced the following bug:

1. User has 2 servers, prio 1 and prio 2
2. All articles are being fetched from server 1
2. Article is missing from server 1, it get's fetched from server 2 so connection is openend to server 2
3. Articles continue on server 1, connection (`NewsWrapper`) to server 2 stays open until the user-defined timeout, default 60 seconds. 
4. CRC error around 50 seconds after step 2, so the article gets requested from the still open connection to server 2.
5. However, the server closed the connection (or something else happens).
6. `__reset_nw` is called, which calls `NzbQueue.reset_try_lists`. Which resets the try_list of the article.
7. So server 1 is tried again for this CRC'ed article

This can continue for ages.. Eventually a job might finish, but if you have a lot of servers (the reporting users had 20+ servers), you will hit the server-timeout server-side before it can finish correctly.

Will fix this by letting `NzbQueue.reset_try_lists` only remove the affected server.

title: article.fetcher and article.fetcher_priority not reset when resetting try list
body:
When testing #1861 I found that when the job is added back to the queue to fetch more par2 files it doesn't do anything at first, only when the bad-try-list check passes it starts downloading.

We do reset the try list when adding extra par2 files, but we don't reset `article.fetcher` and `artucle.fetcher_priority` so it seems to be stuck.

Only reproducible with jobs that are missing on the first-level server and need the second level server.

title: 'unwanted extension' warning repeats after overriding
body:
With _Action when unwanted extension detected_ set to _Pause_, after hitting an unwanted extension a warning is printed and the job gets paused. So far so good.

However, when the users then unpauses the job, new extension warnings keep popping up whenever the directunpacker hits a new file segment (and finds the same extension yet again). This shouldn't happen; instead, the warning should be silenced after the user decides to override the configured pause action.

Note that the issue is only the repeated warning messages; the pause action itself doesn't get repeated.

title: change_complete_action api call should verify input
body: The [api call](https://sabnzbd.org/wiki/advanced/api#change_complete_action) accepts a number of predefined actions as well as scripts in case the supplied _value_ starts with "script_". Unfortunately, the value of the script is not subject to any further checks. As a result, not only do invalid script values get accepted, but, using relative paths (to the script dir), any command on the system can be called. The setting should be limited to only whatever scripts actually exist in the script dir.

title: priority not assigned correctly when importing from watched folder
body:
Hey guys, using SABnzbd 3 from GitHub source/develop on Debian 10.4

When SAB reads my RSS feeds and imports a movie, it correctly assigns the "movies" category and sets the priority to "force" - great!

When SAB reads from my watched folder and imports NZBs, the category is also correctly assigned "movies", but the priority is set to "normal". 

This used to work fine - import them and assign priority "force". How can we fix this? 

Cheers!

title: start_paused switch causes '/queue' to return 'paused' value of 1
body: When using the `start_paused` switch to start the queue as paused, it causes the API call to fetch the queue to return a paused value of `1`, an integer, instead of an expected boolean. In every other situation (including if you toggle the paused/resume state), it returns a boolean of `true` or `false`.

title: Sleep not prevented on macOS
body:
I believe this may be a new issue with recent versions of macOS. 

I'm running macOS Catalina 10.15.5, and SABnzbd 2.3.9 [03c10dc].

When downloading, SABnzbd does does successfully set the PreventUserIdleSystemSleep power assertion. However, I think in newer versions of macOS this does not have the same effect as before. 

At the moment, SABnzbd is not preventing sleep in situations when network access to SABnzbd woke the system. So, in cases of headless operation and remote upload of an NZB, what happens is that the download begins, but the system sleeps within ~30 seconds. 

Looking at other apps that are able to successfully prevent system sleep in headless and remote operation, I believe the power assertion now needs to be set to PreventSystemSleep. 

I think this is a simple change to make in sleepless.py:
https://github.com/sabnzbd/sabnzbd/blob/6d8c264e908e3d9ab0812e016c3eccd8dbe0a8d6/sabnzbd/utils/sleepless.py

Thank you.

title: Reduce size of test-files
body:
Currently the `src` release became 23MB because we also include the `tests` folder.
We should reduce the size of all the test-files to the minimum required.

title: Files can be assembled after the job is removed from the queue
body:
Using the automated testing [I found](https://travis-ci.com/github/sabnzbd/sabnzbd/jobs/349062361#L2500) that in special circumstances it can be that files are still being decoded/assembled while the job has already finished.
It seems to occur because only after the first par2 is received, we postpone the rest of the par2 files we don't need. But in the case of the test and the small files, these were already being downloaded.

Solutions:
- Discard any articles and files after the job was `nzo.deleted`. Have to check the impact when extra par2 is added.
- Post-pone par2 when adding the job.

At first I thought, based on the log output show, that end-of-job was triggered multiple times while parts are still being decoded. This turned out not to be the case, since `nzo.remove_article` is locked, so the end-of-job is really only triggered once. This took me hours of debugging to find out.

title: "Abort jobs that cannot be completed" not working when the post contains 1 large file
body:
Cross posted on support forums; https://forums.sabnzbd.org/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=24797

Articles can be 100% missing, and the job will still continue until its 100%, which is eating a lot of time for content which is missing. https://imgur.com/a/V09HnKf

The "Abort jobs that cannot be completed" flag is set, as is "Fast fail" in special. I can't see any other settings which describe changing this behaviour, so why is SAB not aborting jobs when the available par2 blocks exceed the missing articles?

title: "Check Before Download" results in duplicate backed-up NZB file
body:
If the switch "Check before download" is enabled and a "Watched Folder" is set, it results in a duplicate NZB file in the ".nzb Backup Folder" (if set).

The duplicate NZB file has a shortened name (31 characters).

Is this a bug or the intended outcome?

title: Duplicate Detection doesn't look at filenames
Regression in 2.3.3RC1 when adding NZBs using sabconnect++
body:
I noticed a regression in 2.3.3RC1 when adding NZBs using sabconnect++.

In 2.3.3RC1 when adding NZBs using sabconnect++, while the category is correctly matched, the associated post-processing script is stripped. So you end up with the correct category for the job, it goes in the correct folder, but no post-processing script is selected.

This does not occur in 2.3.2 and 2.3.3 Beta1.

title: Postprocessing/Sorting behaves differently between RAR and 7Zip archive sets
body:
Hi,

Copy and paste of a Reddit post I made in which Safihre request I raise it as a bug over here.  Hope it contains everything needed.

I have a category defined that is linked to the Movie Sorting functionality, simply using the directory name and file extension to end up with a properly named file in my destination directory.  `%dn.%ext`.  When a RAR set is downloaded, this works as expected.
```
/home/username/destinationdirectory/Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP.mkv
```
When a 7Zip set is downloaded it results in a sub directory of the intended name, then the obscured file name.
```
/home/username/destinationdirectory/Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP/876234876acd98798a987a987aaefefef78.mkv
```
When I use a category that doesn't have the renamer enabled, both archive sets result in the same output structure of sub directory properly named then obscured file name, which demonstrates that the archives were created without any additional relative folder structure being included.  To verify I created my own sets of RARs and 7Zips to confirm using.
```
7z a -t7z -mx=0 -r -v105216000b /home/username/outputdirectory7z/test.7z /home/username/sourcefiletopack.mkv
rar a -ep1  -m0 -r -v105216000b /home/username/outputdirectoryrar/test.rar /home/username/sourcefiletopack.mkv
```
From viewing the debug logs RARs have the temporary directory where it has been unpacked to, it renames the obscured name to the real name in the directory, then moves the final file to the directory above (destination directory) and cleans up the temporary directory.
```
    [sorting:633] Renaming Generic file
    [sorting:664] Rename: /home/username/destinationdirectory/Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP/876234876acd98798a987a987aaefefef78.mkv to /home/username/destinationdirectory/Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP/Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP.mkv
    [misc:1108] Renaming "/home/username/destinationdirectory/Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP/876234876acd98798a987a987aaefefef78.mkv" to "/home/username/destinationdirectory/Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP/Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP.mkv"
    [sorting:1088] Give files in set "Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP" matching names.
    [misc:1192] [sabnzbd.misc.cleanup_empty_directories] Deleting dir /home/username/destinationdirectory/Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP
    [misc:1017] Moving (overwrite: 0) /home/username/destinationdirectory/Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP/Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP.mkv => /home/username/destinationdirectory/Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP.mkv
    [misc:1108] Renaming "/home/username/destinationdirectory/Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP/Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP.mkv" to "/home/username/destinationdirectory/Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP.mkv"
    [misc:1192] [sabnzbd.misc.cleanup_empty_directories] Deleting dir /home/username/destinationdirectory/Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP
```
When the 7Zip archive is being processed the debug logs show that the tvsort process only kicks in after the notification email is already sent and is treating it as a TV Show (it never actually does anything to it, just says 'Found TV Show'), even though the Series renamer/sorting system is disabled in my settings and not linked to any categories and the only renaming that occurs is the `_UNPACK_Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP` directory to `Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP` directory containing the obscured name.
```
    [misc:1186] [sabnzbd.newsunpack.seven_extract_core] Deleting file /home/username/destinationdirectory/_UNPACK_Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP/876234876acd98798a987a987aaefefef78.7z
    [postproc:391] unpack_magic finished on Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP
    [misc:1592] Applying permissions 0755 (octal) to /home/username/destinationdirectory/_UNPACK_Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP
    [misc:1592] Applying permissions 0644 (octal) to /home/username/destinationdirectory/_UNPACK_Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP/876234876acd98798a987a987aaefefef78.mkv
    [misc:1192] [sabnzbd.postproc.cleanup_list] Deleting dir /home/username/destinationdirectory/_UNPACK_Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP
    [misc:1192] [sabnzbd.postproc.cleanup_list] Deleting dir /home/username/destinationdirectory/_UNPACK_Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP
    [misc:1108] Renaming "/home/username/destinationdirectory/_UNPACK_Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP" to "/home/username/destinationdirectory/Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP"
    [misc:1192] [sabnzbd.postproc.rename_and_collapse_folder] Deleting dir /home/username/destinationdirectory/_UNPACK_Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP
    [emailer:150] Notification e-mail successfully sent
    [misc:1192] [sabnzbd.postproc.cleanup_list] Deleting dir /home/username/destinationdirectory/_UNPACK_Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP
    [sorting:210] Found TV Show (Filename.S02E02.All.The.Other.Data-GRP)
```
I would have thought that the renaming would be executed by passing the temporary/unpack/working directory to the renamer system once the files existed on the filesystem and by that time the way that they got there should be irrelevant.  

Software versions:
SABnzbd - sabnzbdplus-2.3.2 (rev=1cac5799eb3f74f2e39942453b7b244fb0366e9a) - JCFP non beta PPA repo build.
Python-version = 2.7.14

Any other info needed, let me know.

title: PostProc missing for error
body:
Hey There, 
So I ran into the message "URL Fetching failed; Maximum retries" on a bunch of jobs as I was tuning my search providers in Sickrage but I noticed that this does not trigger postprocessing to send a Failed result to nzbToMedia and updating the Sickrage to search for the next best result.  I believe this makes sense.

title: Endless waiting for non-existing servers
body:
Recently NextGenNews went offline, resulting in many users having jobs "stuck", like some [here](https://forums.sabnzbd.org/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=23151).
I now see that SAB just keeps endlessly retrying to resolve offline servers. There is no logging or timeout at all.

title: If first par2-file is broken, already downloaded par2 files are ignored
body: The code expects no other par2 files to be downloaded yet, so if `Download all par2` is turned on the job is just failed because no second par2 file is tried.

title: SABnzbd 2.3.0 doesn't run on 10.9, 10.10 and 10.11.
body:
I've tried every 2.3.0 build, alpha1, alpha2, rc1, rc2 and final.

The previous stable, 2.2.1, runs perfectly.

They report the same error message: 
“SABnzbd.app” is damaged and can’t be opened. You should move it to the Trash"

 spctl --assess --continue --verbose /Applications/SABnzbd.app
/Applications/SABnzbd.app: a sealed resource is missing or invalid

and yet:

codesign -v --verbose /Applications/SABnzbd.app
/Applications/SABnzbd.app: valid on disk
/Applications/SABnzbd.app: satisfies its Designated Requirement

Console logs:
CoreServicesUIAgent[300]: Error SecAssessmentCreate: The operation couldn’t be completed. (OSStatus error -67055.)
Error -60005 creating authorization

This is on a user's computer that had issues running 2.3.0.

Has something changed concerning code signing since 2.2.1?

title: "Maximum retries" is not actually number of retries per server, but per priority level
body:
After digging deep to find the source of stalling issues, I have found that `article.tries` actually counts the number of tries per priority-level and not per-server.
This causes a problem when you have this set to 3 and you have 4 servers on the same priority. 
Additionally there is a problem with resetting the `TryList` when a server times out.

Still searching for a memory and CPU efficient way to keep the correct count.

title: URL grabber unhandled exception
body:
I am am on Ubuntu 12.4 with SAB 2.0.0 Beta 1 from the PPA. Unsure if this is the latest, but I am aware my boxen is about 5 weeks since last update.

A NZB URL was inserted by Sickbeard and SAB crashed on downloading it. It's not stuck in a "Trying to fetch" state. More importantly, the URL grabber crashed error occurred.

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/share/sabnzbdplus/sabnzbd/urlgrabber.py", line 215, in run
    data = fn.read()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/socket.py", line 351, in read
    data = self._sock.recv(rbufsize)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/httplib.py", line 598, in read
    s = self.fp.read(amt)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/socket.py", line 380, in read
    data = self._sock.recv(left)
error: [Errno 104] Connection reset by peer
```

Reviewing the file object in use in the grabber, I note it is as `socket._fileobject` coming from a `urllib2.HTTPResponse`. `urllib2` is unsafe for partially returned data, as the file object it constructs has already read the headers, which is enough to help the library assume it is working. If the connection collapses at any point after headers, exceptions should be expected.

As the error is coming out of `socket`, this needs handling rather than just the current `IncompleteRead` handler in urlgrabber.

Pull request amends this handling to capture IOError as well, which is a parent of `socket.error` in Python 2.6 and above. It also drops the exception captured in `e` as this is presently unused.

title: par2cmdline ignores the first file of a joinable
body:
Putting this here so other will know, since there is no complete fix. Only tested it on Windows so far.
Sparked by: https://forums.sabnzbd.org/viewtopic.php?f=11&t=22560

---

With joinable posts that are 100% complete par2-tbb will detect all the files but fail the joining with the usual `Could not write ..`, so a retry is done with par2cmdline.
However, for some magical crazy reason, par2cmdline just doesn't scan the `.001` file, only all the other ones. It doesn't matter how I supply it, either with a wildcard or listing all the files. I tried everything and all possible notations (`\\?\ or `\\.\` or regular).
If I list the file twice in the command, it will correctly report `Ignoring duplicate file x.001`, but then proceed just not to scan it:
```
Verifying source files:
Target: "[DameDesuYo] Chaos Dragon - 12 (1280x720 10bit AAC) [E066CBC4].mkv" - missing.
Scanning extra files:
Scanning: "[DameDesuYo] Chaos Dragon - ...0bit AAC) [E066CBC4].mkv.002": 1.2%
```
This will cause then SAB to download all extra par2 files and then fail due to missing blocks because par2cmdline wants to reconstruct the whole 1st file, even though all files are already 100% complete.

Crazy enough: par2-tbb will not throw the `Could not write ..` error if the download is not 100% complete and needs actual repair. It then repairs and joins just fine..

Therefore I will implement the following 'fix' that will only works if par2-tbb is not disabled: if there are joinables and par2-tbb reports `Repair is possible` but then fails with the `Could not write ..` error, return success so we can continue to join the files.

body:
I run sabnzbd from source on Linux and am on the latest dev version. I use RSS feeds quite a lot, and there is now a problem with them. I first noticed this problem on Wednesday, 2017-01-18. It took me a while to see what is happening. 

It seems to me that every time a new item in one of my RSS feeds is found and downloaded, then that feed's portion in rss_data.sab gets corrupted somehow. At least when I try to access these feeds in sabnzbd I get a 500 server error and a traceback is displayed in red. It's also in the logs:

title: Avoid problems with illegal filenames on Windows
body:
On Windows, SABnzbd cannot properly handle job names and filenames starting with reserved names (e.g. "con.", "aux.").
Currently the URL-grabber and the queue handler will block when trying to create such files, blocking further operation.
At least the blocking should be prevented.
Given that we must use par2cmdline, we cannot solve the problem completely, but at least the blocking of other jobs must be prevented.
Suggestion: as soon a an illegal filename is detected, send  the job as failed to History along with a clear error message.

Initial attempt to fix the URL-grabber #771

title: Set hard limit on Decoder-queue

milestone.description:
Speed optimizations.
Improved SSL (with verification and cypher choice).
Combined RSS feeds

body:
The calculation of memory usage for articles in the Decoder-queue is not correct, which can cause slow growth of that Queue and its corresponding memory usage.

Tried multiple ways to calculate a correct size, but python's `sys.getsizeof(data)` doesn't return the right amount. So for now, as a safety patch, set a hard limit of 100 articles.
This is oke because the problem is actually the smaller articles, which take relatively longer to go through the whole decode process than bigger ones.

title: OS X: Bundled unrar has wrong permissions set.
body:
On the Mac OS X version the bundled copy of unrar (SABnzbd.app/Contents/Resources/osx/unrar/unrar) has its permissions set to 700 instead of 755, resulting in SABnzbd being unable to use unrar when it's run as a different user from the one that installed it.

The bug is present in versions 1.0 and 1.0.1.

title: Downloading of articles while SABnzbd being Paused

milestone.description:
New features.
- Proper login screen
- Optimizations in download

body:
This is an issue I've been seeing since 0.7.x and still exist in 0.8.0 beta 5.

Configuration - Schedule:
00:00 Daily Resume
12:00 Daily Pause All

Purpose: download from midnight till noon and not during the afternoon nor evenings.

NZBs can still be added while SABnzbd is on Pause, queuing up the work that'll kick off at midnight. If one of those items in the queue is one I don't want to wait upon, I switch it it's priority to Force which starts the download. All the other NZBs in the queue should remain Paused.

SABnzbd starts downloading the one having Priority set to Force, but some articles of the next item get also downloaded while the last articles of the NZB that I had switched to Force, are being retrieved. In other words, downloading of articles is overflowing to the next NZBs in the queue.

I have a primary usenet server and a few optional block servers configured. What can happen is that the NZB I switched to Force is getting downloaded till 95% completeness, and at the end it needs to obtain the remaining articles from a block server which can be a lot slower. During that time, SABnzbd starts to download articles of the next NZB in the queue, which state is set to Pause so it should not be downloading any articles. As these are getting downloaded from my fast primary usenet server, there can be a significant amount of 'overflowing'. 

Worst case scenario I came discovered today. I have an NZB in the queue that ran till 99% with a few dozen articles remaining. It got stuck in the queue at 99% as the username/password of one my block accounts got expired, causing "Authentication failed, check username/password". The current state, while having SABnzbd set to Paused, any new NZB I add automatically starts downloading, despite them not having priority set to Force. Expected behavior is for any new ones to be queued up.

This behavior poses a risk for users whom have a download limit enforced by their ISP.

title: Themes display misleading speed limit when using absolute values
body:
Max line speed set to 125M
Speed limit set to an absolute value of 3M using API.
Plush and Simpl displays 2%, Gliiter displays 2% - 2.5MB/sec
I assume this is the rounded percentage of max line speed represented by 3M.
This should be 2.4%, but since the speed-limit UI element doesn't display floats, it gets rounded down to 2%.
The speed-limit enforced is actually 3MB/sec, so it's purely a UI issue.

body:
In 0.8 failed jobs (on Windows) never have the status retry:1
Looking at the code, failed jobs should get retry:1 if the job-download-dir is still there.. But seems this check always fails.
Maybe this is because of the long directory name support making any of these functions fail?
**starts_with_path(path, cfg.download_dir.get_path()) and \
os.path.exists(path)) and \
not bool(globber(os.path.join(path, JOB_ADMIN), 'SABnzbd_n*')**

title: newsunpack.py: local variable 'new_joins' referenced before assignment
body:
See http://forums.sabnzbd.org/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=17509 . Error:

2014-05-11 22:06:28,372::INFO::[postproc:506] Traceback: 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "sabnzbd\postproc.pyo", line 347, in process_job
  File "sabnzbd\newsunpack.pyo", line 240, in unpack_magic
UnboundLocalError: local variable 'new_joins' referenced before assignment

I checked newsunpack.py, and if "cfg.enable_filejoin()" is false, new_joins is not set, which can lead to that message. Code:

```
if cfg.enable_filejoin():
    new_joins = [jn for jn in xjoinables if jn not in joinables]
```

new_joins can be used in line 240 even if it was not set. So I would say that's a bug.
